awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Informal Foundation of Authoritarian Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
General Summary

The political durability and economic accomplishments of authoritarian regimes under the single-party government have long interested social scientists and policymakers, especially since these regimes lack the liberal institutionalism that scholars typically associate with development and good governance. This project seeks to cast a new perspective on single-party government resilience by probing the informal dimension of the system. More specifically, it focuses on how networks of patron-client relations structure political interactions among party elites and shape the broader patterns of political and economic development at both the national and subnational levels.  Contrary to the conventional wisdom that views informal, clientelistic relations as primarily a cause for corruption, political instability and economic decay, this project argues that they actually contribute to the single-party government's resilience by serving as a key organizational mechanism that mobilizes, incentivizes, and coordinates actors in a system where the formal institutions are poorly equipped to perform such functions. Using China as the case of interest, this project contributes to a growing body of research on the role of informal institutions in political and economic governance. The project also offers new data and methods for reconstructing the social world of Chinese political elites since the 1990s. 

Technical Summary

This project seeks to cast a new perspective on single-party government resilience by probing the informal dimension of the system. The research project seeks to systematically measure the presence of informal networks among Chinese elites and evaluate their impacts on the following four dimensions: (1) political institutionalization, (2) economic development, (3) policy implementation, and (4) anticorruption enforcement. The main quantitative evidence is drawn from an original biographical database of over 4,000 politicians at city, provincial, and national levels since early 1990s. The project develops new automated algorithms for identifying patron-client ties by linking lower-level officials with political superiors who oversaw their major promotions in the past, and leverages carefully chosen natural experiments to estimate the causal effects of informal networks. To supplement the quantitative analyses, the PI will also conduct in-depth interviews with serving and retired officials in both central and local governments, and collects additional historical and archival materials during his fieldwork in China.

por.por_cntn:
The main output of the project was the co-PI (Junyan Jiang)'s dissertation, Fragmented Unity: Patronage Politics and Authoritarian Resilience in China. Departing from the prevailing view of the literature that authoritarian regimes extend their longevity primarily by revamping their institutions to mimic (although imperfectly) their democratic counterparts, the dissertation offers an alternative perspective for understanding the the political durability of China, the largest authoritarian country in the world, by tracing its roots to the enduring and informal aspect of the system. Focusing on the intra-elite patron-client networks, the dissertation argues that, contrary to the conventional view that they are merely a symptom of backward and corrupt patrimonial regimes, these informal networks make important contributions to the stability and effectiveness of the regime by fostering trust and cooperation among political actors in an environment where credibility is usually in short supply. The coordination capacity that these networks afford in turn helps support the proper functioning of formal institutions and allows elites to engage in collective undertakings that address some of the most pressing problems that the regime faces. 

By bringing informal politics into the analysis of China's resilience, the study helps reconcile several conflicting images about the nature of the system. My framework explain, for example, why the party state can operate with a highly fragmented political and governing structure (Landry, 2008; Lieberthal et al., 1988) and yet at the same time exhibit a high degree of unity and effectiveness in accomplishing essential policy tasks (Birney, 2014; Rothstein, 2014); relatedly, it also explains why a bureaucracy characterized by with widespread patrimonialism and corruption (Shih et al., 2012; Wedeman, 2012) is still able to supply high-powered performance incentives to its agents (Li et al., 2005; Xu, 2011). The dissertation's analysis suggests that these seemingly contradictory phenomena may, in fact, be deeply interconnected and share the same origin in the same set of informal dynamics that govern the system: Informal bargains that strengthen the unity among the elites may also involve a demarcation of key turf and spoils that will perpetuate the influence of major factions, and personal bonds that facilitate cooperation between the principals and the agents can also be mobilized for public causes as well as less legitimate goals, such as power consolidation and self-enrichment. The coexistence of these paradoxical images, therefore, is not necessarily a sign of a dysfunctional regime, but may rather be the evidence that the system is working, only according to its own logic. 


More broadly, the dissertation builds on and contributes to the literature on comparative authoritarianism. This analysis builds on prior research's insights that authoritarian regimes face threats from both the mass and within the elites and that the political environment in which elites interact is characterized by a low level of trust and credibility (Acemoglu et al., 2008; Tullock, 1987; Svolik, 2012). Since the seminal work of Geddes (1999); Geddes (2003), a burgeoning line of research has examined how authoritarian regimes create and adapt formal institutions to address both sources of threats and to sustain intra-elite cooperation. Researchers have shown that formal, semi-democratic institutions such as parties, legislatures, and elections, can play important roles in co-opting opposition (Gandhi, 2008; Blaydes, 2010), regulating elite behaviors (Brownlee, 2007; Magaloni, 2008), alleviating problems of information asymmetry between the dictators and their ruling coalitions (Boix et al., 2007), and promoting foreign investments and economic growth (Wright, 2008). However, there is still a dearth of research on the role of informal institutions in autocratic systems, despite a general consensus that the most important rules of politics in those systems are still largely unwritten. This study thus complements and extends this literature's common focus on formal institutions by providing an in-depth analysis of how informal institutions such as patron-client networks shape the political dynamics in one of the largest contemporary authoritarian regimes.

The award has been used to support the co-PI's research trip to China as well as several major data acquisition initiatives. The trip involved several interviews with government officials, business figures, and journalists and materials collected from these interviews later became and integral part of the dissertation. In addition, the co-PI also used the award to acquire several large-scale datasets including a comprehensive database on law and regulations (2000-2016), a dataset of over 3 million land transaction records between 2003 and 2013, 900,000 petitions from a major national-level online petition forum, 3 million Weibo posts from 7,000 popular social media accounts, and 11 national surveys on private firms (1997-2012). These datasets have significantly aided the empirical analyses in the dissertation.
